result.markdown:
---
title: 'Select and rename columns'
order: 1
---






Open the tidyverse package, and read the data from the URL.





::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
library(tidyverse)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr}

```
── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.4
✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.1
✔ ggplot2   3.4.4     ✔ tibble    3.2.1
✔ lubridate 1.9.3     ✔ tidyr     1.3.1
✔ purrr     1.0.2     
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
url <- "https://raw.githubusercontent.com/fivethirtyeight/data/master/poll-quiz-guns/guns-polls.csv"
d <- read_csv(url)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr}

```
Rows: 57 Columns: 9
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
chr (6): Question, Start, End, Pollster, Population, URL
dbl (3): Support, Republican Support, Democratic Support

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.
```


:::
:::





## Selecting certain columns

Where `filter` selects specific rows, `select` allows you to select specific columns. 
Most simply, we can simply name the columns that we want to retrieve them in that particular order. 





::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
select(d, Population, Support, Pollster)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
# A tibble: 57 × 3
   Population        Support Pollster          
   <chr>               <dbl> <chr>             
 1 Registered Voters      72 CNN/SSRS          
 2 Adults                 82 NPR/Ipsos         
 3 Adults                 67 Rasmussen         
 4 Registered Voters      84 Harris Interactive
 5 Registered Voters      78 Quinnipiac        
 6 Registered Voters      72 YouGov            
 7 Registered Voters      76 Morning Consult   
 8 Registered Voters      41 YouGov/Huffpost   
 9 Adults                 44 CBS News          
10 Adults                 43 Rasmussen         
# ℹ 47 more rows
```


:::
:::





You can also specify a range of columns, for example all columns from Support to Democratic Support:





::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
select(d, Support:`Democratic Support`)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
# A tibble: 57 × 3
   Support `Republican Support` `Democratic Support`
     <dbl>                <dbl>                <dbl>
 1      72                   61                   86
 2      82                   72                   92
 3      67                   59                   76
 4      84                   77                   92
 5      78                   63                   93
 6      72                   65                   80
 7      76                   72                   86
 8      41                   69                   20
 9      44                   68                   20
10      43                   71                   24
# ℹ 47 more rows
```


:::
:::





Note the use of 'backticks' (reverse quotes) to specify the column name, as R does not normally allow spaces in names. 

Select can also be used to rename columns when selecting them, for example to get rid of the spaces:





::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
select(d, Pollster, rep = `Republican Support`, dem = `Democratic Support`)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
# A tibble: 57 × 3
   Pollster             rep   dem
   <chr>              <dbl> <dbl>
 1 CNN/SSRS              61    86
 2 NPR/Ipsos             72    92
 3 Rasmussen             59    76
 4 Harris Interactive    77    92
 5 Quinnipiac            63    93
 6 YouGov                65    80
 7 Morning Consult       72    86
 8 YouGov/Huffpost       69    20
 9 CBS News              68    20
10 Rasmussen             71    24
# ℹ 47 more rows
```


:::
:::





Note that `select` drops all columns not selected. If you only want to rename columns, you can use the `rename` function:





::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
rename(d, start_date = Start, end_date = End)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
# A tibble: 57 × 9
   Question start_date end_date Pollster Population Support `Republican Support`
   <chr>    <chr>      <chr>    <chr>    <chr>        <dbl>                <dbl>
 1 age-21   2/20/18    2/23/18  CNN/SSRS Registere…      72                   61
 2 age-21   2/27/18    2/28/18  NPR/Ips… Adults          82                   72
 3 age-21   3/1/18     3/4/18   Rasmuss… Adults          67                   59
 4 age-21   2/22/18    2/26/18  Harris … Registere…      84                   77
 5 age-21   3/3/18     3/5/18   Quinnip… Registere…      78                   63
 6 age-21   3/4/18     3/6/18   YouGov   Registere…      72                   65
 7 age-21   3/1/18     3/5/18   Morning… Registere…      76                   72
 8 arm-tea… 2/23/18    2/25/18  YouGov/… Registere…      41                   69
 9 arm-tea… 2/20/18    2/23/18  CBS News Adults          44                   68
10 arm-tea… 2/27/18    2/28/18  Rasmuss… Adults          43                   71
# ℹ 47 more rows
# ℹ 2 more variables: `Democratic Support` <dbl>, URL <chr>
```


:::
:::





Finally, you can drop a variable by adding a minus sign in front of a name:





::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
select(d, -Question, -URL)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
# A tibble: 57 × 7
   Start   End     Pollster           Population    Support `Republican Support`
   <chr>   <chr>   <chr>              <chr>           <dbl>                <dbl>
 1 2/20/18 2/23/18 CNN/SSRS           Registered V…      72                   61
 2 2/27/18 2/28/18 NPR/Ipsos          Adults             82                   72
 3 3/1/18  3/4/18  Rasmussen          Adults             67                   59
 4 2/22/18 2/26/18 Harris Interactive Registered V…      84                   77
 5 3/3/18  3/5/18  Quinnipiac         Registered V…      78                   63
 6 3/4/18  3/6/18  YouGov             Registered V…      72                   65
 7 3/1/18  3/5/18  Morning Consult    Registered V…      76                   72
 8 2/23/18 2/25/18 YouGov/Huffpost    Registered V…      41                   69
 9 2/20/18 2/23/18 CBS News           Adults             44                   68
10 2/27/18 2/28/18 Rasmussen          Adults             43                   71
# ℹ 47 more rows
# ℹ 1 more variable: `Democratic Support` <dbl>
```


:::
:::
